required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Autologous Cord Blood Mononuclear Cells for Bronchopulmonary Dysplasia in Very Preterm Neonates
clinical_study.official_title: Autologous Cord Blood Mononuclear Cells for Bronchopulmonary Dysplasia in Very Preterm Neonates

brief_summary.textblock:
Rationale: Pre-clinical animal studies provide robust evidence regarding the beneficial effect of cord blood-derived mononuclear cells (MNCs) for experimental bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD).
This single-center, randomized, controlled, blinded trial assessed the effect of a single intravenous infusion of autologous cord blood MNCs (ACBMNCs) in preventing BPD in very preterm neonates, a high-risk population.

primary_outcome.measure: bronchopulmonary dysplasia at 36 weeks of postmenstrual age or the discharge home
primary_outcome.time_frame: 36 weeks of postmenstrual age or the discharge

secondary_outcome.measure: number of patients with severe BPD in survivors
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 36 weeks of postmenstrual age or the discharge

secondary_outcome.measure: number of patients died before discharge from hospital

arm_group.description: Autologous Umbilical Cord Blood Mononuclear Cells Therapy 24 hours after birth ,dose is 50 million cells/kg
0.9% sodium chloride infusion 24 hours after birth

intervention.intervention_name: Autologous Umbilical Cord Blood Mononuclear Cells Therapy
intervention.description: Autologous Umbilical Cord Blood Mononuclear Cells Therapy in preterm for prevention of infection

criteria.textblock: Inclusion Criteria: (1) born at the study hospital; (2) singleton birth; (3) GA <32 weeks; (4) free of severe congenital anomalies or genetic syndromes; (5) without clinical chorioamnionitis; (6) the mother was negative for hepatitis B (HBsAg and/or HBeAg), hepatitis C (anti-HCV), syphilis, HIV (anti-HIV-1 and -2), and IgM against cytomegalovirus, rubella, toxoplasma, and herpes simplex viruses; (7) consent was obtained from the parents or guardians; and (8) after processing, UCB cells were available.
